did.unittitle: Grand Hotel (Mackinac Island, Mich.) records circa 1855-2012 1946-2012
did.abstract: The Grand Hotel records comprise documents, photographs, audio and videographic material collected about the hotel by its management. The strength of the collection is in its documentation of the guest experience at the hotel, and the evolution of amenities offered by the hotel during the mid-to-late 20th century. A small number of items also provide a glimpse of the hotelâ€™s earliest days as a summer resort.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was received from Grand Hotel (donor no. 9662) beginning in October 2005; additional materials have been received.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research. Copying for commercial purposes requires the permission of the donor.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.
Duplication Policy: Copying for commercial purposes requires the permission of the donor.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Grand Hotel (Mackinac Island, Mich.) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Grand Hotel opened on July 10, 1887 as a venture of the Mackinac Island Hotel Company. In 1910, the hotel was purchased by Henry Weaver, its manager since 1900. The hotel was sold again in 1918, this time to J. Logan Ballard, who died only five years later. In 1925, William Stewart Woodfill purchased the hotel with two other men, to whom he later sold his shares. In 1933, Woodfill would purchase the hotel again, this time as sole owner, after it fell into receivership. Woodfill, who also managed the hotel for a number of years, retained ownership throughout the mid-20th century, though he gradually turned responsibility for the hotel's management over to Dan Musser beginning in 1951. The Musser family purchased the hotel from Woodfill in 1979, and continue to run it today.

Since its opening, Grand Hotel has become a popular family vacation destination and conference location with its upscale accommodations and dining facilities. Features of the hotel include an elaborate, multi-course dinner included for every guest, 18 holes of golf, a 660-foot front porch overlooking the water, and a pool that Esther Williams made famous in the movie This Time For Keeps in 1946.

Information for this History was taken from Grand Hotel: The biography of an American institution by John McCabe. This book, published by the hotel on the occasion of its centennial season, is available in box 1 of the papers, and includes images of historical documents owned by the hotel and other repositories that are not included in this collection.

scopecontent.p: The Grand Hotel records are arranged in six series: Printed Material, 1901-2007; Miscellaneous, 1935-1992; Press Clippings and Publications, 1965-2011; Photographic Material, 1855-2004; Audio Material, 1981-2007; and Videographic Material, 1980-2011.

Printed Material, ca. 1920- 2007, comprises mostly materials printed for use in the regular course of the hotel's business, such as brochures, menus, guest identification/information booklets, and similar items. Items of note include an early brochure featuring photographs of guest rooms (stored as an oversize item) and a subseries of menus used at the hotel throughout the 20th century. Also included in this series is a copy of the hardbound book Grand Hotel: The biography of an American institution by John McCabe.

odd.p: (also one oversize item in folder Bb Outsize)

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous, 1935-1992, comprises a small number of internal memoranda, a proof sheet for a page reprinting a Ripley's Believe It or Not regarding Grand Hotel's porch and the text of a speech dedicating Grand Hotel as a National Historic Landmark in 1990.

did.unittitle: Proof sheet for page reprinting a Ripley's Believe It or Not regarding Grand Hotel's porch 1986
Grand Hotel Centennial Weekend July 10-12, 1987 and other celebrations
Text of speech dedicating Grand Hotel as a National Historic Landmark 1990
"Michigan's Island Innkeeper," in Saturday Evening Post June 4, 1960

scopecontent.p: The Press Clippings and Publications series comprises newspaper and magazine articles about Grand Hotel that were saved by its public relations office.

Photographic Material, 1855-2004 comprises over 2,200 images organized in 5 subseries. Hotel Amenities, Scenery and Unidentified Events comprises images of the hotel, its surroundings, and general unidentified events. The bulk of the images in this subseries are from the mid-20th century through the late 1980s. The Events subseries comprises images of identified events that were held at the hotel, and includes numerous photographs of celebrities and political leaders. People contains images featuring notable personages and staff members, and includes several images of Woodfill and the Musser family. Construction and Remodeling contains almost entirely snapshot images of construction projects that were conducted at the hotel during its off-seasons, mainly during the 1980s. Finally, the Miscellaneous subseries contains images of the recovery work after a room fire at the hotel in 1983, as well as photographic reproductions of several artistic and historical items related to the hotel.

scopecontent.p: Photographs that were once displayed on the walls of the Grand Hotel can be found in the Display Photographs, 1856-1995 subseries. Beginning in 2006, a small group of photographs were transferred to the Bentley Historical Library. The Bentley scanned, color corrected, and printed copies of these photographs and returned the copies to the Grand Hotel; the originals are preserved in this collection. Some photographs are severely faded due to years of sun exposure. The display photographs have been divided into similar groupings as the Photographic Material: Hotel and Grounds, Mackinac Island, Events, People, and Construction. Additional accruals to this series are expected.

scopecontent.p: Audio Material, 1993-2000 comprises both commercial compact discs of music performed by Grand Hotel's musical staff, as well as radio advertisements promotions and interviews.

scopecontent.p: Videographic Material, 1980-2011 comprises mainly tapes of television shows that featured Grand Hotel or its staff. Highlights of this series include interviews with executives and employees of the hotel, as well as videographic images of the hotel and its surroundings. Also included in this series are two commercially produced videocassettes on Mackinac Island and its history.
